description: From Middle French siphon, from Old French sifon, from Latin sipho, from Ancient Greek σίφων (síphōn, “pipe, tube”), of uncertain origin; possibly related to Latin tibia (“pipe, flute of bone”), reflecting a hypothetical late Proto-Indo-European *twi-, *twibʰ- (“hollow”) root, but the irregular forms suggest a non-Indo-European loan (i.e. substrate) source.

entries.meaning: A bent pipe or tube with one end lower than the other, in which hydrostatic pressure exerted due to the force of gravity moves liquid from one reservoir to another.
(biology) A tubelike organ found in animals or elongated cell found in plants.

verbs.description: siphon (third-person singular simple present siphons, present participle siphoning, simple past and past participle siphoned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To transfer (liquid) by means of a siphon.
examples: He used a rubber tube to siphon petrol from the car's fuel tank.

entries.meaning: (transitive, figurative) To steal or skim off money in small amounts; to embezzle.
